head.title: Isles' Late Comeback Falls Short, and Sabres Advance

hedline.hl1: Isles' Late Comeback Falls Short, and Sabres Advance
hedline.hl2: Isles’ Late Comeback Falls Short, and Sabres Advance

block.p: In the end, the Islanders still had a chance. The team that had to win its final four games of the regular season simply to qualify for the playoffs had a chance to tie Game 5 of its opening-round playoff series with nine seconds remaining on a shot from close range by Miroslav Satan.
But Buffalo Sabres goaltender Ryan Miller stopped him on a brilliant sprawling save.
After pulling within a goal with seven minutes left, the Islanders pressed their attack, but they could not get the puck past Sabres goalkeeper Ryan Miller, who finished with 30 saves.

In the end, the Islanders still had a chance. The team that had to win its final four games of the regular season simply to qualify for the playoffs had a chance to tie Game 5 of its opening-round playoff series with nine seconds remaining on a shot from close range by Miroslav Satan.
But Buffalo Sabres goaltender Ryan Miller stopped him on a brilliant sprawling save.

With that, the Islanders lost, 4-3, and their season -- one in which they seemed to be continually trying to overcome bad breaks -- finally ended. The Sabres won the series, four games to one, after a furious Islanders rally fell short.
The loss was the Islanders' third in a row, and it came on a day when the team was rocked by a suspension.

Hours before the game, the National Hockey League announced that defenseman Sean Hill had become the first player suspended under the league's policy for testing for performance-enhancing drugs. The policy has been in effect since the new collective-bargaining agreement was signed in July 2005.

With Hill out of the lineup, the Islanders finally cracked under strains that began to show earlier in the week. But not before mounting a comeback from a 3-0 deficit against the Sabres, who led the league in scoring and had the best record in the N.H.L. during the regular season.

With seven minutes remaining, the Islanders pulled to 4-3 on a goal by defenseman Chris Campoli. They continued to pepper Miller, who made a number of clutch saves, none more important than his spectacular blind stop of Satan in the game's waning seconds.
After that save, Miller smothered the puck, preventing Alexei Yashin from poking in the rebound. Miller finished with 30 saves.
''We were close,'' said Ryan Smyth, the Islanders' leading scorer in the series with 4 points. ''Close isn't good enough. If you think that, that's the wrong mentality, in my mind.''

Buffalo appeared to put the game away by jumping to a 3-0 lead. The rookie forward Drew Stafford scored first, wheeling into the slot with the puck and shoveling a backhand past Islanders goalie Rick DiPietro for his first career playoff goal.

Buffalo took a 2-0 lead 39 seconds into the second period. Daniel Brière stripped the puck from Satan in the Islanders' zone, then fed a pass to Jason Pominville in the slot. Pominville beat DiPietro to the short side.
Derek Roy scored Buffalo's third goal on a rebound at 11 minutes 29 seconds of the second.
DiPietro was not as sharp as he had been in three previous games. He finished with 23 saves.
The Islanders' offense came to life early in the third period. Satan scored at 4:22 when he sent a backhand along the ice.
Just over two minutes later, Maxim Afinogenov restored the Sabres' three-goal lead.
But Trent Hunter pulled the score to 4-2 at 9:43, putting in the rebound of a shot from the point by Bruno Gervais. Campoli scored three minutes later, setting up Miller's star turn.
''We got to that point where we were holding on,'' Miller said of his save on Satan. ''That was a heck of a battle. They really turned it up in the third.''

Last Saturday, the Islanders tied the series at one game apiece, receiving an emotional boost and a 3-2 victory in Game 2, when DiPietro returned after missing three weeks with postconcussion symptoms.

But in Games 3 and 4 at Nassau Coliseum, the Islanders showed signs that they were coming unglued. A disputed goal by the Sabres in Game 3, and a disputed nongoal by the Islanders in Game 4, began a kind of bad luck theme.

Then came the news that Hill was being suspended for 20 games for violating the league's policy on performance-enhancing drugs. Hill, 37, was in Buffalo on Friday, but he did not participate in the pregame skate.
General Manager Garth Snow told reporters before the game that the Islanders supported the suspension. He refused to answer questions, and Hill's teammates refused to comment on the suspension.
